article.title: Terrestrial Planets Formation under Migration: the Systems near 4:2:1 Mean Motion Resonance

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the orbital evolution of planetesimals and a Jupiter-mass planet. What phenomenon is responsible for the planetesimals being scattered outward into high-eccentricity orbits?
choices: Type I migration of the planetesimals
Type II migration of the Jupiter-mass planet
Gravitational scattering by the Jupiter-mass planet

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the evolution of semi-major axis and eccentricity for a simulation with a Jupiter-mass planet undergoing type II migration and two inner planets undergoing type I migration. What significant orbital configuration do the three planets eventually achieve?

This figure shows the orbital evolution of planetesimals and a stationary Jupiter-mass planet.  Compared to Figure 1, where the Jupiter-mass planet migrates inward, what is the key difference in accretion rate observed in this scenario?
choices: The accretion rate is significantly higher in Figure 3.
The accretion rate is significantly lower in Figure 3.
The accretion rates are roughly the same in both figures.
The figure does not provide information about accretion rates.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts the final configurations of three simulations (S1, S4, S5) that resulted in a 4:2:1 MMR. What do the color variations of the solid points representing terrestrial planets signify?
choices: The color indicates the eccentricity of each planet.
The color indicates the composition of each planet.
The color indicates the mass of each planet.
The color indicates the formation time of each planet.
